dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON A FACE.  A nine year old boy, YOUNG COLE, his ey with wonder. watching something intently.  We HEAR the so the P.A. SYSTEM droning Flight Information mingled with t sounds of urgent SHOUTS, running FEET, EXCLAMATIONS. YOUNG COLE'S POV:  twenty yards away, a BLONDE MAN is spr the floor, blood oozing from his gaudy Hawaiian shirt. A BRUNETTE in a tight dress, her face obscured from YOUNG view, rushes to the injured man, kneels beside him, minis to his wound. ANGLE ON YOUNG COLE, flanked by his PARENTS, their faces view, as they steer him away. FATHER'S VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Son --this is no place for us. YOUNG COLE resists momentarily, mesmerized by the drama. YOUNG COLE'S POV:  intermittently visible through a confu FIGURES rushing through the foreground, the BLONDE MAN re up and touching the cheek of the kneeling BRUNETTE in a g of enormous tenderness, a gesture of farewell, while the SYSTEM continues its monotonous monotone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flight 784 for San Francisco is now ready for boarding at inmate number 66578, Greely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --number 5429, Garcia -- number 87645, Cole... COLE, late thirties, dark hair, comes awake in a bunk cag of many stacked four high along both sides of a long dim corridor.  He blinks in the near dark, shaken, disoriente Then, as he "recovers" from his very vivid dream, WE GET

dialogues.speaker: "DREAMLIKE" THAN HIS DREAM.
dialogues.text: Flashlights glare. In the half-light, COLE sees spooky fi GUARDS, moving among the locked bunk/cages. COLE turns and whispers to the occupant of the next cage,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssssst!  Jose, what's going on? JOSE's face is almost lost in shadow.  What there is of i youthful.  He's just a scared Puerto Rican kid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Volunteers" again. JOSE immediately rolls over and feigns sleep as SCARFACE, menacing guard with a jagged scar running down his cheek, close to COLE's cage and unlocks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Volunteer duty". The PRISONERS in the other cages watch silently with narr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't volunteer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You causing trouble again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (controls his temper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLE's alone, struggling to get into what looks like a sp in a room where suits hang like ghosts with blank eyes. TITLES BEGIN SUPERED OVER THE SCENE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLE has the torso of the suit on now and is trying to cl OFFSCREEN VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All openings must be closed. COLE looks for the source of the voice, a tiny grate in t OFFSCREEN VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the integrity of the suit is compromised in any way, if the fabric is torn or a zipper not closed, readmittance will be denied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLE, wearing the "space suit" and a helmet with a plasti steps into a tiny chamber, a kind of air lock.  The heavy clangs shut behind him.  He's alone.  COLE'S breath comes now as he sucks oxygen from the air tanks on his back. On the opposite wall is another door with a huge wheel lo COLE turns the heavy wheel, opens the door, steps through

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLE'S in an ascending elevator that groans and creaks. down at a crudely drawn map he holds in his gloved hand. The map shows a series of tunnels and ladders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLE pans a flashlight, probing the filthy sewer he's wad RATS flee the blade of light, scurry across islands of ru The flashlight beam settles on a ladder mounted in the wa Reaching the rusted ladder, COLE starts to climb awkwardl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SCRAPING NOISE as a heavy man-hole cover is pushed up a aside.  COLE'S helmeted head emerges from below. COLE'S POV THROUGH HIS PLASTIC-VISORED HELMET:  a city in moonlight!  A surreal image of abandoned buildings.  No p anywhere.  The only sounds are the WIND and COLE'S BREATH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLE'S light reveals abandoned vine-covered automobiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving to the nearest car, COLE searches in the vines for something.  Finds it.  An insect. COLE takes the bug in his gloved hand.  As he clumsily in into a collection tube, something makes him turn. There's something across the street in the dark.  Somethi COLE points his flashlight and reveals...a BEAR!  Startle light, the animal blinks, then stands on its rear legs an ANGLE ON COLE, staring wide-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, the BEAR sinks down onto all fours and, trying to a flashlight, it pads quickly down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Using the flashlight to see, COLE reaches down to the cra floor and gets another specimen.  DOGSHIT! The only sound is COLE'S labored BREATHING. Then, a different SOUND.  GRRRR!  A dog.  More GRRRRS.  M dogs.  Then, a YIP.  Then, VICIOUS GROWLS.  It's a DOGFIG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A giant OWL, perched on an overhead traffic light, raises and lifts off...rising higher and higher into the brighte Below, on the street, COLE trudges along, passing deserte buildings, windows broken, rusted signs dangling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLE'S light reveals a spider web just inside the store. SPIDER tries to hide from the light. COLE reaches carefully into the web and plucks the spider puts it into one of his specimen tubes. Then, he shines his light all around the once elegant sto nothing but aisle after aisle of moldering consumer goods

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As COLE comes out of the store, the first rays of the sun building.  COLE stops, squints into the light through his COLE'S POV:  spray-painted on the wall a long time ago is logo of twelve monkeys holding hands in a circle.  Over i written, "WE DID IT!" COLE looks up. COLE'S POV:  high up on a building across the street, a L patrols a ledge, pauses, looks out majestically over his TTTLES END

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROARING WATER, powerful torrents gushing from nozzles in wall, pummel the still-suited COLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stark naked and shivering, COLE is being scrubbed with br long poles (like the ones used to wash cars) wielded by t FIGURES in bulky decontamination suits, their personas lo windowed masks.  It's a grim scene in a grim cement room dripping walls.  From an unseen source comes an AMPLIFIED AMPLIFIED VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raise your arms above your head. COLE lifts his arms and the FIGURES start scrubbing his a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still naked, COLE is seated on a stool while a MASKED TEC in a less elaborate, less bulky decontamination outfit dr blood from COLE'S arm with an old-fashioned hypodermic ne COLE glances toward a single, nearly opaque "window" of t plastic in the rusty iron wall.  VAGUE FIGURES seem to lu behind the translucent aperture, studying him. The TECHNICIAN slips the blood sample through a slot in t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ushered in by two guards, TINY and SCARFACE, COLE looks a COLE'S POV:  wails hidden by old headlines, articles, map a blackboard covered with elaborate, sophisticated formul heaped with cracked monitors, gerry-rigged computers held string, lasers lost in tangles of cable, ancient tube amp dilapidated cardboard reconstruction of a city, stacks of books and tattered computer printouts...and, seated at a table, staring at COLE, six SCIENTISTS:  an ASTROPHYSICIS BOTANIST, MICROBIOLOGIST, ZOOLOGIST, and a GEOLOGIST.  Th a "modern" science where brilliant new ideas interface wi outdated, patched-together technologies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James Cole.  Cleared from quarantine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  You two wait outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a history, Doctor.  Violence. COLE'S eyes return to the walls. Headlines:  "CLOCK TICKING!  NO CURE YET!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anti-social six -- doing 25 to life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think he's going to hurt us.  You're not going to hurt us, are you Mr. Cole? COLE'S head turns quickly to the ENGINEER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. The GUARDS exchange a look, shrug, exit, closing the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you sit down, Mr. Cole. COLE goes to the empty chair at the conference table, sit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want you to tell us about last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to the surface and I collected specimens like I was told. The SCIENTISTS don't say anything.  They just study him c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mashed the spider, didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get to the spider later, Mr. Cole.  Right now, we want to know everything that you saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLE, starting to look very tired now, stands at the blac sketching a detailed map of exactly where he was last nig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you collected sample #4, what street was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's important to observe everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it was...I'm sure it was 2nd Street. As the SCIENTISTS start to whisper animatedly among thems COLE'S eyes drift across the newspaper clippings taped to wall.  One headline screams, "VIRUS MUTATING!"  Another f a photo of an OLD MAN (DR. MASON, who we'll see again lat and the words, SCIENTIST SAYS, "IT'S TOO LATE FOR CURE". ASTROPHYSICIST'S VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close your eyes, Cole. Startled, COLE closes his eyes obediently. BLACKNESS.  Like COLE, WE SEE NOTHING.  But we HEAR their ENGINEER'S VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us in detail what you've seen in this room. COLE'S VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, in this room?  Uh... MICROBIOLOGIST'S VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many of us are there? COLE'S VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six...seven, if you count me. ASTROPHYSICIST'S VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us about the pictures on the wall... COLE'S VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, you mean the newspapers? A MONTAGE OF OVERLAPPING VOICES (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us about the newspapers.  Can you hear my voice?  What do I look like? What does he look like, the man who just spoke?  How old were you when you left the surface? The VOICES blur into a cacophony and FADE INTO the dronin SYSTEM at the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DREAM AGAIN!  But at an earlier moment.  YOUNG COLE, by his PARENTS, whose faces are out of view, is watching land through one of the big glass windows that lines the leading to the departure gates. P.A. SYSTEM (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flight 784 now boarding at gate... Suddenly, a SHOUT, followed by raised VOICES, interrupts monotonous airport routine.  As YOUNG COLE and his PARENT to see what's going on, a man we'll call MR. PONYTAIL, hi averted, hurries past them, bumping YOUNG COLE with a Chi Hulls Sports Duffle Bag.

dialogues.speaker: WATCH IT
dialogues.text: YOUNG COLE sees little more than the gaudy pants, the duf the man's ponytail flopping as he rushes towards the gate Just then, a WOMAN'S VOICE cries out, "NOOOOOOOOO!" YOUNG COLE turns back toward the Security Check Point jus TRAVELERS scatter madly, some diving to the floor, others running.  A TERRIFIED TRAVELER, hitting the floor close b up at YOUNG COLE with panicky eyes, and asks....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just exactly why did you volunteer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLE comes abruptly awake.  Seated now, he's facing the S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up, Cole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, I didn't hear the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tapping a pencil on the table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked you, why did you volunteer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the guard woke me up.  He told me I volunteered. The SCIENTISTS react, whispering urgently among themselve COLE starts to nod off again, then comes awake with a sta the ENGINEER speaks to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We appreciate you volunteering.  You're a very good observer, Cole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll get a reduction in sentence. COLE keeps his face impassive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be determined by the proper authorities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to jeopardize that reduction, do you, Cole?  Have it taken away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a very advanced program, something very different, requires very skilled people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An opportunity to reduce your sentence considerably...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And possibly play an important role in returning the human race to the surface of the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want tough minded people.  Strong mentally.  We've had some...misfortunes with "unstable" types.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a man in your position...an opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to volunteer could be a real mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tapping his pencil again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Definitely a mistake! COLE gives away nothing.  He's in a box here.  He has no He stares at the tapping pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A strikingly "real" world of bright colors.  Extravagant adorn the walls.  A POET, tiny and ruddy faced, squints o glasses as he reads in a booming voice to an AUDIENCE of seated on folding chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still among the myriad microwaves, the infra-red messages, the gigabytes of ones and zeroes, we find words, infinitesimally small, byte-sized now, tinier even than science lurking in some vague electricity where, if we listen we can hear the solitary voice of that poet telling us, "We are no other than a moving row Of Magic shadow-shapes that come and go Round with the Sun-illumined Lantern hold In Midnight by the Master of the show." As the POET reads, we STUDY the audience, mostly YUPPIE C JUNKIES or BOHEMIANS.  Among them, a light-haired woman o eight, soberly dressed, wearing glasses.  She's KATHRYN R it's her beeper that suddenly BEEPS.  BEEP!  BEEP! POET'S VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Moving Finger writes; and, having writ, Moves on:  nor all your Piety nor Wit Shall lure it back to cancel half a Line, Nor all your Tears wash out a Word of it." BEEP!  BEEP!  Scowling at the outrageous interruption, th looks up from the text just as RAILLY, tumbling, shuts of beeper and rises, embarrassed.  As she makes her way to a the glaring POET continues...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Yesterday This Day's Madness did prepare; Tomorrow's Silence, Triumph or Despair: Drink!  for you know not whence you came, nor why: Drink!  for you know not why you go, nor where."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DETECTIVE FRANKI leads RAILLY past crowded holding cells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- so they get there and they ask the guy real nice for some kind of i.d., and he gets agitated, starts screaming about viruses. Totally irrational, totally disoriented, doesn't know where he is, what day it is, alla that stuff.  All they got was his name.  They figure he's stoned out of his mind, it's some kinda psychotic episode, so they're gonna bring him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been tested for drugs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Negative for drugs.  But he took on five cops like he was dusted to the eyeballs.  No drugs.  You believe that? FRANKI pauses, indicating a tiny observation window of th glass in an otherwise solid door, and RAILLY looks throug RAILLY'S POV THROUGH THE WINDOW:  a MAN, his back to her, strait-jacket and prison denims, examining the wall of th cell with the distorted intensity of a "mental case".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have him in restraints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you listening?  We got two officers in the hospital.  Yeah, he's in restraints, plus the medic gave him enough stellazine to kill a horse.  Look at him!  Still on his feet. RAILLY'S POV THROUGH THE WINDOW:  the MAN in the cell tur right at her.  In spite of the cuts and welts, it's clear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would explain the bruises, I guess.  The struggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to go in?  Examine him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, please.  You said he gave a name...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unlocking the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James Cole.  That's everything we got.  None of the James Coles on the computer match him. No license, no prints, no warrants.  Nothing. You want me to go in with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right here...just in case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLE stares at RAILLY.  The environment is intensely real colors...each sound, however slight, very distinct, almos and yet she appears to him almost like a vision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cole?  My name is Doctor Railly. I'm a psychiatrist.  I work for the County -- I don't work for the police. My only concern is your well being -- do you understand that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to go now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to be completely honest.  I'm not going to lie to you.  I can't make the police let you go...but I do want to help you.  And I want you to trust me.  Can you do that, James?  May I call you "James"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "James"!  Nobody ever calls me that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowns, studies him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been a patient at County? Have I seen you someplace?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not possible.  Listen, I have to get out of here.  I'm supposed to be getting information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of information?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't help you.  You can't do anything about it.  You can't change anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Change what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know why you're here, James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'm a good observer.  Because I have a tough mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.  You don't remember assaulting a police officer...several officers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wanted identification.  I don't have any identification.  I wasn't trying to hurt them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have a driver's license, James?  Or a Social Security card?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?  Most people have some ID.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been in an institution, haven't you, James?  A hospital?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A jail?  Prison?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Underground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love this air.  This is wonderful air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wonderful about the air, James?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so clean.  No germs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're afraid of germs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you think there aren't any germs in the air, James?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is April, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: July.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sudden panic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: July?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what year it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What year is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What year do you think it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think it's July of 1995?  That's the future, James.  Do you think you're living in the future?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slightly confused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, 1995 is the past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1995 is the future, James.  This is 1989. COLE looks stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLE, bound tightly by the strait-jacket, heavy manacles ankles, is being escorted down the corridor by two surly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you taking me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: South of France, buddy.  Fancy hotel. You're gonna love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: South of France?!  I don't want to go to the South of France.  I want to make a telephone call. POLICEMAN #2 smirks as he unlocks a heavy steel door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zip it, scumbag -- you fooled the shrink with your act, but you don't fool us. Then, POLICEMAN #2 swings the steel door open and sunligh overwhelms COLE, blinding him in a dazzling fury of white

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Mini-van, the kind of vehicle used to transport a half prisoners, crawls through a busy street.  The Police Depa logo is prominent on the side of the van beneath barred w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fierce spray recalls the decontamination in the future. stands stark naked under the shower while two muscular at PALMER and BILLINGS, supervise. As PALMER shuts off the water, BILLINGS hands COLE a towe starts inspecting his scalp...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme see your head, Jimbo, see if you got any creepy crawlies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to make a telephone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling Cole's head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta work that out with a doctor, Jimbo. Can't make no calls 'til the doctor says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What chew gotta do, Jimbo, is take it easy, relax into things.  We all gonna get along fine if you just relax. COLE gets the hint of menace in the message and submits t lice inspection, only his eyes revealing his frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLE stands in the doorway, stunned by his first sight of large room.  His eyes go to the heavily-grilled windows w light pours in from outside.  Then, to the TV, where a CA COMMERCIAL makes raucous noises. PATIENTS, in K-Mart street clothes or ratty robes, stare at the TV, or play cards, pace, or just stare blankly. BILLINGS is at COLE'S side, beckoning to a patient, JEFFR a twenty year old white youth dressed in khakis and a pla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeffrey.  Yo!  Jeffrey.  This here is James. Whyncha show James around?  Tell him the TV rules, show him the games an' stuff, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a sly look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much you gonna pay me?  Huh?  I'd be doing your job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five thousand dollars, my man.  That enough?  I'll wire it to your account as usual, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Billings.  Five thousand.  That's enough.  Five thousand dollars.  I'll give him the Deluxe Mental Hospital Tour. As BILLINGS walks away chuckling, JEFFREY turns to COLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kid around, kid around.  It makes them feel good, we're all pals.  We're prisoners, they're the guards, but it's all in good fun, you see? COLE nods and JEFFREY indicates card tables where PATIENT playing cards, checkers, chess, or working on jig saw puz

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the games.  Games vegitize you. If you play the games, you're voluntarily taking a tranquilizer. COLE sees a partially completed puzzle of the well-known THE PEACEABLE KINGDOM, depicting a serene world of animal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd they give you?  Thorazine?  How much?  Learn your drugs -- know your doses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to make a telephone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A telephone call?  That's communication with the outside world!  Doctor's discretion.  Hey, if alla these nuts could just make phone calls, it could spread.  Insanity oozing through telephone cables, oozing into the ears of all those poor sane people, infecting them!  Whackos everywhere!  A plague of madness. (suddenly sly and confidential)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact, very few of us here are actually mentally ill.  I'm not saying you're not mentally ill, for all I know you're crazy as a loon.  But that's not why you're here.  Why you're here is because of the system, because of the economy. (indicating the TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the TV.  It's all right there. Commercials.  We are not productive anymore, they don't need us to make things anymore, it's all automated.  What are we for then?  We're consumers.  Okay, buy a lot of stuff, you're a good citizen. But if you don't buy a lot of stuff, you know what?  You're mentally ill! That's a fact!  If you don't buy things...toilet paper, new cars, computerized blenders, electrically operated sexual devices... (getting hysterical)

dialogues.speaker: ACTIVATED COMPUTERS, AND...
dialogues.text: A woman orderly, TERRY, turns from the feeble PATIENT she

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, Jeffrey.  Be calm. Abruptly, JEFFREY stifles his hysteria, takes a deep brea continues, completely calm now.  But COLE isn't listening mesmerized by the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So if you want to watch a particular program, say "All My Children" or something, you go to the Charge Nurse and tell her what day and time the show you want to see is on.  But you have to tell her before the show is scheduled to be on.  There was this one guy who was always requesting shows that had already played.  He couldn't quite grasp the idea that the Charge Nurse couldn't just make it be yesterday for him, turn back time ha ha.  What a fruitcake!! This last thought actually penetrates COLE'S focus on the he turns to JEFFREY who's picking up speed again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously, more and more people are being defined now as mentally ill.  Why? Because they're not consuming on their own.  But as patients, they becone consumers of mental health care.  And this gives the so-called sane people work! (hysteria again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, that's it, Jeffrey, you're gonna get a shot.  I warned you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calming himself, smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right!  Right!  Carried away, heh heh. I got "carried away".  Explaining the workings of...the institution. Just then, TJ WASHINGTON, a somber-looking African Americ bathrobe, taps COLE on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't really come from outer space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is TJ Washington, Jim -- he doesn't really come from outer space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mock me, my friend. (to Cole)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a condition of "mental divergence". I find myself on another planet, Ogo, part of an intellectual elite, preparing to subjugate barbarian hordes on Pluto. But even though it's a totally convincing reality in every way...I can feel, breathe, hear...nevertheless, Ogo is actually a construct of my psyche.  I am mentally divergent in that I am escaping certain unnamed realities that plague my life here.  When I stop going there, I will be well.  Are you also divergent, friend? The P.A. SYSTEM interrupts, startling COLE. P.A. SYSTEM (v.o.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James Cole.  Report to Staff.  James Cole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staff!  Whoo!  Time for Staff.  Now the geniuses cure you.  Hallelujah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLE is agitated, speaking forcefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a place for crazy people!  I'm not crazy! RAILLY, four other PSYCHIATRIC RESIDENTS, including RAILL friend, MARILOU MARTIN, and their chief, DR. OWEN FLETCHE around a beat-up conference table, watching COLE, who sit the doctors, with BILLINGS looming behind him.  (Some of bear a strong resemblance to the SCIENTISTS OF THE FUTURE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't use that term..."crazy", Mr. Cole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you've got some real nuts in here! Listen to me, all of you -- I have to tell you something that's going to be difficult for you to understand, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James...please.  These are all doctors here and we want to help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cole -- last night you told Dr. Railly you thought it was... (checking a file)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1995. ... How about right now?  Do you know what year it is right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1989.  Look, I'm not confused.  There's been a mistake, I've been sent to the wrong place. Suddenly, COLE reaches out and BILLINGS lunges forward, b is just grabbing a pad and pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm not going to hurt anybody. FLETCHER restrains BILLINGS with a hand signal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drawing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do any of you know anything about the Army of the Twelve Monkeys?  They paint this, stencil it, on buildings, all over the place. COLE waves a sketch of the dancing monkey logo we saw ear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cole...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  I guess you wouldn't, this is 1989, they're probably not active yet. That makes sense!  Okay.  Listen to me, three billion people died in 1995. Three billion, got that?  Almost the whole population.  Of the world! Only about one percent survived. DOCTORS exchange knowing looks.  This is an old story, ap

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to save us, Mr. Cole?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save you?  How can I save you?  It already happened!  I can't save you.  I'm simply trying to get some information for people in the present so that someday... (sees their eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't believe me.  You think I'm crazy.  But I'm not crazy.  I'm a convict, sure, I have a quick temper, but I'm as sane as anyone in this room.  I... COLE stops, sees DR. FLETCHER tapping his pencil.  COLE'S that tapping before -- in the future!  It disorients him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you tell us the name of the prison you've come from? COLE doesn't answer.  He's staring at the tapping pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does this bother you, Mr. Cole?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (recovering, new tack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  Look, I don't belong here!  What I need to do is make a telephone call to straighten everything out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who would you call, Mr. Cole, who would straighten everything out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scientists.  I'm supposed to report in to them.  They'll want to know they sent me to the wrong time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you could talk to these scientists and they do what?  Send you to the future?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no.  I can't talk to them.  It's called, "voice mail".  I'm supposed to leave messages. They monitor it from the present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "From the present."  We're not in the present now, Mr. Cole?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no.  This is the past.  This has already happened.  Listen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cole, you belong in 1995 -- that's the present, is that it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, 1995 is the past, too.  Look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These scientists, Mr. Cole?  Are they doctors like ourselves? Two of the residents exchange quick knowing looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  I mean yes, but... Look, I've been given a lot of drugs but I'm still perfectly lucid. You have to let me use the phone.  One call! COLE looks desperately toward RAILLY, pleading eyes meeti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four little KIDS SCREAM and SQUABBLE while the phone CHIR insistently in the tiny, cluttered apartment and a harrie lunges for the phone, answers sharply...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? (listens, frowns, then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whaaaaat?  "Voice mail"!  I don't know what you're talkin' about. ... Is this a joke?  I don't know any scientists. James who?  Never heard of you! The MOTHER slams down the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dismayed COLE still has the receiver in his hand.  Symp RAILLY takes it from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't who you expected? COLE is clearly agitated, starts to pace, upset.  Nuts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was some lady.  She didn't know anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps it was a wrong number...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  That's the reason they chose me -- I remember things. RAILLY frowns, studying the distracted man with intense i It's clear COLE is becoming a special patient and RAILLY' detached demeanor is giving way ever so slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James, where did you grow up?  Was it around here?  Around Baltimore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lost in thought)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have the...strangest feeling I've met you before...a long time ago, perhaps. Were you ever...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait!  This is only 1989!  I'm supposed to be leaving messages in 1995.  It's not the right number yet.  That's the problem.  Damn!  How can I contact them? RAILLY recovers her distance, her poise, as she takes a b pours out some tablets, and holds them out to COLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James, take these. (watching him step back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please -- I helped you like I said I would.  Now I want you to trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. PONYTAIL races past the startled YOUNG COLE.

dialogues.speaker: WATCH IT
dialogues.text: Was it JEFFREY wearing gaudy pants and a ponytail?  It wa definitely JEFFREY'S VOICE. TRAVELERS dive for cover as a WOMAN'S VOICE cries out...

dialogues.speaker: NOOOOOOOOOO
dialogues.text: The TERRIFIED TRAVELER looks up at YOUNG COLE, makes eye doesn't speak.  The TERRIFIED TRAVELER looks a lot like D Just then, YOUNG COLE is distracted by a running figure. the BLONDE MAN in the Hawaiian shirt, but he's not injure sprinting toward the gates, glancing back over his should moustache slightly askew! A sharp CRACK of a GUNSHOT rings out!  Then, DAZZLING LIG Everything goes white!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLE'S eyes blink awake, blinded by a flashlight. He's lying in one of thirty beds in a darkened ward.  Dis Which world is this?  The room is full of BREATHING, SNOR occasional MOANS.  He can barely discern the shadowy figu an ORDERLY and a NURSE, making their rounds, checking eac His eyes adjusting to the darkness, COLE watches them exi He turns and sees a patch of moonlight coming in a barred With a quick glance at the sleeping PATIENTS, he slips ou bed, makes his way stealthily to the window, peers out. COLE'S POV:  the moon, glowing in the sky, illuminating a tree.  Under the tree, in silhouette, a COUPLE embraces, ANGLE ON COLE, looking out the window, absorbed. VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't work. You can't open it. Alarmed, COLE turns, sees JEFFREY in the next bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you can remove the grill but you can't.  It's welded. COLE checks the grill anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See?  I toldja.  And all the doors are locked, too.  They're protecting the people on the outside from us.  But the people outside are as crazy as us. COLE has become preoccupied with a small SPIDER creeping the window sill.  He's staring at it when he's distracted sudden SOUND.  Grabbing the SPIDER, COLE scrambles back i just as the door opens and an ORDERLY probes the dark roo the blade of his flashlight. ANGLE ON COLE, in bed, feigning sleep. The flashlight clicks off and COLE hears the door close. For a long moment the ward is silent except for BREATHING SNORES, occasional MOANS.  Then, COLE hears JEFFREY'S hoa whisper, picking up right where he left off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what "crazy" is?  "crazy" is "majority rules".  Take germs for example. Although COLE is preoccupied with the SPIDER struggling t out of his fist, he can't help reacting to the word, "ger

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Germs?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the 18th century there was no such thing!  Nobody'd ever imagined such a thing -- no sane person anyway.  Along comes this doctor...Semmelweiss, I think.  He tries to convince people... other doctors mostly...that there are these teeny tiny invisible "bad things" called germs that get into your body and make you...sick!  He's trying to get doctors to wash their hands.  What is this guy...crazy?  Teeny tiny invisible whaddayou call 'em?..."germs"! As JEFFREY warms to his subject, getting excited, COLE tr figure out where to put the SPIDER. JEFFREY (cont.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So cut to the 20th century!  Last week in fact, right before I got dragged into this hellhole.  I order a burger in this fast food joint.  The waiter drops it on the floor.  He picks it up, wipes it off, hands it to me...like it was all okay. No alternative.  COLE pops the SPIDER in his mouth and sw it as JEFFREY prattles on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "What about the germs?"  I say.  He goes, "I don't believe in germs.  Germs are just a plot they made up so they can sell you disinfectants and soap!" Now, he's crazy, right?  Hey, you believe in germs, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not, I never thought you were. You want to escape, right?  That's very sane.  I can help you.  You want me to, don't you?  Get you out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you know how to escape, why don't you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't I escape, that's what you were going to ask me, right?  'Cause I'd be crazy to escape!  I'm all taken care of, see?  I've sent out word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've managed to contact certain underlings, evil spirits, secretaries of secretaries, and assorted minions, who will contact my father. When he learns I'm in this kind of place, he'll have them transfer me to one of those classy joints where they treat you...properly.

dialogues.speaker: FOR THE NUT CASE LUNATIC MANIAC DEVILS...
dialogues.text: PATIENTS are waking up as the NURSE and two ORDERLIES bur dorm and head straight for JEFFREY who's struggling to ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.  Really sorry.  Got a little agitated.  The thought of escaping crossed my mind and suddenly...suddenly I felt LIKE BENDING THE FUCKING BARS

dialogues.speaker: THEM, AND LEAPING, LEAPING...
dialogues.text: COLE watches the ORDERLIES grab JEFFREY and haul him away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You dumb assholes!  I'm a mental patient! I'm supposed to act out.  Wait til you morons find out who I am.  My father's gonna be really upset.  AND WHEN MY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON TV SCREEN/A VIDEO IMAGE OF A LAB MONKEY, convuls pathetically, a victim of shocks from the numerous wires to his tiny, restrained body. ANGLE ON COLE, sitting, writing intensely in a magazine w crayon, surrounded by dull-eyed PATIENTS in pajamas and r robes, staring at the shuddering LAB MONKEY on the TV scr JEFFREY'S VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Torture!  Experiments!  We're all monkeys COLE locks up, startled, as JEFFREY, one eye bruised blac the seat next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hurt you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not as bad as what they're doing to kitty. ANGLE ON TV, showing a laboratory CAT turning in mad circ eating its own tail, while a NEWS REPORTER narrates. TV NEWS REPORTER (v.o.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These video tapes were obtained by animal rights activists who worked underground as laboratory assistants for several months.  Authorities say there is little they can do until... The video footage now shows LAB WORKERS watching the resu their experiments passively. ANGLE ON COLE, reacting angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at those assholes, they're asking for it!  Maybe people deserved to be wiped out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled, turning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wiping cut the human race!  That's a great idea!  But it's more of a long term thing -- right now we have to focus on more immediate goals. (sudden whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say a word about "you know what".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about???

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know -- your plan. As COLE stares, befuddled, JEFFREY sees COLE'S magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you writing?  You a reporter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shielding the magazine)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's private.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lawsuit?  You going to sue them? Just then BILLINGS looms over COLE, extending a cup full

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo, James -- time to take your meds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON THE TV, a commercial playing:  a beautiful coupl in the surf in slow motion while an eager NARRATOR encour NARRATOR (v.o.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a chance.  Live the moment.  Sunshine. Gorgeous beaches.  The Florida Keys! ANGLE ON COLE, very drugged, seated in front of the TV al other drugged PATIENTS, staring at the screen. ANGLE ON THE TV, showing a picture of the Marx Brothers. TV AWNOUNCER (v.o.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll return to the Marx Brothers in "Monkey Business" following these messages. JEFFREY'S VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monkey Business!  Monk Key Business. COLE sees JEFFREY sliding into the next chair and smirkin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get it?  Monk - Key.  Monk! (big grin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Key! JEFFREY flashes his palm open for one quick moment.  A KE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (groggy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wooooo, they really dosed you, bro. Major load!  Listen up -- try and get it together.  Focus!  Focus!  The plan! Remember?  I did my part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What...???

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not, "what", babe!  When! "When???"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pressing the key into Cole's hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now! VOICE/TV (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us guide you to the stocks and bonds that will enhance your portfolio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaping to his feet)

dialogues.speaker: NO MORE MONKEY BUSINESS
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON TV, almost mimicking JEFFREY with an ad...a BULL BEAR and a computer screen showing stock prices fluctuati VOICE/TV (v.o.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A portfolio tailored to your specific needs and the needs of your loved ones... ANGLE ON COLE, dumbfounded, watching JEFFREY dance crazil

dialogues.speaker: YES, YES. ENHANCE YOUR PORTFOLIO NOW
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON BILLINGS, across the ward, reacting to JEFFREY, of the OLD MAN he's helping as another orderly, TERRY, pr beeper, calling for help. ANGLE ON COLE, flabbergasted, as JEFFREY cavorts around t

dialogues.speaker: BUY
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON A HAND, inserting the last piece into the PEACEA KINGDOM JIGSAW PUZZLE.  Just then, JEFFREY'S HAND sweeps puzzle off the table, scattering it into a thousand piece ANGLE ON JEFFREY, dancing away while the PATIENT who just completed the puzzle stares, very upset. Other PATIENTS are getting agitated, too, as JEFFREY avoi lunge by BILLINGS and dances off, using PATIENTS as a shi

dialogues.speaker: YES
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON COLE, realizing through the haze of drugs that J is sending a message to him.  COLE looks at the ward door COLE'S POV:  the WARD DOOR opens and two husky ORDERLIES One locks the door with a key, one of many on a key ring to his belt, as the other ORDERLY rushes to join the purs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (missing a tackle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn you, Jeffrey, quit playing the fool. ANGLE ON COLE, hesitating.  He locks at the door...blurri and out of focus.  He looks down at the key in his hand. ANGLE ON JEFFREY, being grabbed by the ORDERLIES.  JEFFRE resists wildly as they struggle to overpower him.

dialogues.speaker: LAST CHANCE
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON COLE, moving to the door.  He reaches it and tri insert the key in the lock. ANGLE ON LOCK, as the key keeps missing the hole. ANGLE ON COLE, glancing nervously over his shoulder. COLE'S POV:  ORDERLIES swarm over JEFFREY, don't notice C ANGLE ON COLE, managing to insert the key.  It won't turn A PATIENT, close at hand, startles COLE, speaking into hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Place to go would be...Florida.  The keys are lovely this tine of year. COLE, unnerved, desperate tries the key again.  It turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful.  J. Edgar Hoover isn't really dead. COLE pauses, stares, not understanding.  Then, he opens t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stepping through the door, COLE finds himself in an ante- facing several elevators. A uniformed SECURITY MAN sitting at a near-by desk doesn' lock up from the magazine he's reading. Barely daring to breathe, COLE steps toward the elevators back is to the SECURITY MAN.  But he doesn't know how to this elevator.  What should he do? SECURITY MAN'S VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two's not working today.  Use one. COLE freezes, sneaks a glance over his shoulder. COLE'S POV:  the SECURITY MAN continues his reading.  He' guy with reading glasses perched on his nose.  He looks e like the MENACING GUARD IN THE FUTURE...SCARFACE! ANGLE ON COLE, stunned! Just then, an elevator door slides open.  The elevator's COLE steps into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door closes, isolating COLE in the elevator. COLE finds the down button, is about to push it when the springs to life.  The numbers on the indicator over the d start to rise.  7...8...9. Then, the elevator stops and the door opens. Two DOCTORS and an AIDE stand in front of the door, waiti COLE hesitates. They look at him.  They seem to expect him to exit. Avoiding eye contact, COLE exits the elevator. As they enter the elevator, the DOCTORS look back at COLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAILLY has just arrived for work.  She's slipping on her doctor's coat when... DR. CASEY, one of the other residents, sticks his head in door waving a crayoned message on a page torn from a maga

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was in my box, but I have a slight suspicion it wasn't meant for me. CASEY enters the room, reading the scrawled words dramati

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "You are the most beautiful woman I have ever seen.  You live in a beautiful world.  But you don't know it.  You have freedom, sunshine, air you can breathe."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole.  James Cole -- right? She reaches for the note but CASEY moves it out of her gr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I would do anything to stay here, but I must leave.  Please, help me."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor man... CASEY is handing her the note when another resident, DR. sticks his head in the door.  He's upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Kathryn, James Cole is one of yours, right? RAILLY and CASEY stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got out.  Took off.  Last seen, he was up on nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PATIENT is being swallowed by a large tube, a CAT SCANN while a DOCTOR in a white coat speaks reassuringly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just relax -- don't fight it.  We have to know exactly what's there so we can... The DOCTOR stops, astonished, as the door bursts open. It's COLE!  He stares at the PATIENT and the Cat Scanner. The PATIENT lifts his head up and stares at COLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh, excuse me.  Can I help you? COLE turns and rushes back out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLE steps into the corridor, turns to his right, freezes A POSSE of SECURITY GUARDS is headed in his direction. COLE turns to his left. Four ORDERLIES are coming that way. COLE'S trapped.  A beat.  He attacks the nearest man.  BI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAILLY prepares a hypo, turns to COLE who is strapped tig a gurney with BILLINGS and an RN standing on either side, for more trouble.  One of BILLINGS' eyes is starting to s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a shot to calm you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more drugs.  Please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to do this, James.  You're very confused. RAILLY pushes the needle into COLE'S skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. FLETCHER faces RAILLY across the conference table.  D CASEY, DR. GOODINS, DR. MARILOU MARTIN are also there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be defensive, Kathryn, this isn't an inquisition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think I was being defensive. I was just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He should have been in restraints.  It was bad judgment on your part, plain and simple.  why not just cop to it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, it was bad judgment.  But I have the strangest feeling about him -- I've seen him somewhere and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatient, not interested)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two policemen were already in the hospital and now we have an orderly with a broken arm and a Security Officer with a fractured skull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said it was bad judgment!  What else do you want me to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see what I mean?  You're being defensive. (to Dr. Casey)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't she being defensive, Bob? But just then, BILLINGS sticks his head in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Dr. Fletcher -- we got another... situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. FLETCHER looks into an empty padded cell as RAILLY, M GOODIN, BILLINGS, PALMER and the NURSE crowd behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was in full restraints?  And the door was locked?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  Did it myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he was fully sedated?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was fully sedated!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then are you trying to tell me that a fully sedated, fully restrained patient somehow slipped out that vent, replaced the grill behind him and that he's wriggling through the ventilation system right now? DR. FLETCHER indicates an impossibly tiny vent high in th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen through the glass windows, a 747 takes off, climbing the sky as the airport P.A. System drones...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flight 784 to San Francisco now boarding at Gate 38... YOUNG COLE, watching the 747, whirls at the SOUND of a CO MR. PONYTAIL bumps him. The BLONDE MAN sprints past.  The WOMAN'S VOICE calls out

dialogues.speaker: NOOOOOOOOOO
dialogues.text: TRAVELERS dive for cover briefly revealing the mysterious running after the BLONDE MAN!  But this time, YOUNG COLE just a glimpse of her face.  She looks a little like RAIL for the dark hair, the make-up. and the flashy earrings. calls out, her VOICE blending weirdly with the P.A. SYSTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Freedom For Animals Headquarters now boarding on Second Avenue.  The Army of the Twelve Monkeys... ENGINEER'S VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole, you moron -- wake up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As COLE blinks awake, the digitized monotone of the P.A. continues to drone in an unearthly VOICE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- they're the ones who are going to do it... COLE'S eyes seek the source of the sound and find it on t in front of the panel of disapproving SCIENTISTS facing h a beat-up old tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do anything more.  The Police are after me. The tape ends, runs off the reel, flap...flap...flap...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's drugged out of his mind!  He's completely zoned out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole, did you or did you not record that message?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, that message...me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a digital reconstruction of a message, Cole, from a weak signal on our contact number.  Did you make that call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't call!  You sent me to the wrong year!  It was 1989.
The SCIENTISTS react, exchanging looks, whispers.  Then,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're certain of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (before Cole can answer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do with your time, Cole? Did you waste it on drugs?  Women?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They forced me to take drugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forced you!  Why would someone force you to take drugs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got into trouble.  I got arrested. But I still got you a specimen -- a spider -- but I didn't have anyplace to put it, so I ate it.  It was the wrong year anyway, so I guess it doesn't matter. The SCIENTISTS stare incredulously, then turn, exchange k looks, huddle, start whispering to one another. Struggling to stay awake COLE sees, blurrily, the MICROBI staring at COLE intently.  For one moment, the face belon

dialogues.speaker: DR. FLETCHER
dialogues.text: COLE blinks hard...and the MICROBIOLOGIST has his own fac COLE'S head slumps forward now...and everything goes dark GEOLOGIST'S VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLE comes awake with a start.  The room is dark now, exc a slide is being projected on a torn screen.  It's a pict stenciled graffiti...the logo of The Army of the 12 Monke

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about it, Cole?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, no, sir.  I... Another slide CLICKS into place.  Youthful PROTESTERS, th placards featuring slogans and images of Animal Atrocitie confront POLICE in riot gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about these people?  Did you see any of these people? Zooming in, panning, the SCIENTISTS emphasize the FACES o PROTESTERS.  The FACES are unfamiliar to COLE (though WE recognize some of them later on). COLE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, no, sir, I...wait! The image pans back to a much enlarged blurry FACE among PROTESTERS.  In spite of the poor image, the expression o is clear, and it seems to resemble a somewhat older JEFFR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him?  You saw that man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, I think so.  In the mental hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (switching on the light)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were in a mental institution?! The SCIENTISTS MUTTER disapprovingly among themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were sent to make very important observations!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could have made a real contribution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helped to reclaim the planet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As well as reducing your sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The question is, Cole -- "Do you want another chance?" COLE stares at them, trying to figure out what they mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BRUNETTE runs up the concourse, her back to YOUNG COL frightened PASSENGERS duck for cover, SHOUTING! RASPY VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLE opens his eyes.  Where is he?  Silence as he examine tiny cell.  Bare cement walls.  High ceiling.  Same color size as the isolation room at the county hospital. RASPY VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Bob...what's your name? COLE looks around frantically.  Up, down.  Where is the V coming from?  Maybe from that tiny vent high in the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you? RASPY VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can talk!  Wah'dja do, Bobby boy? Volunteer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's not "Bob". RASPY VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a prob, Bob.  Where'd they send you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you? RASPY VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another cell. ...  Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, "maybe"?  What's that supposed to mean? RASPY VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.  Means "maybe" I'm in the next cell, another "volunteer" like you -- or "maybe" I'm in the Central Office spying on you for all those science bozos.  Or, hey, "maybe" I'm not even here.  "Maybe" I'm just in your head.  No way to confirm anything. Ha Ha.  Where'd they send you? COLE doesn't answer. RASPY VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not talking, huh, Bob?  That's okay I can handle that.
RASPY VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 89!  How was it?  Good drugs?  Lotsa pussy?  Hey, Bob, you do the job?  D'ju find out the "big info"?...Army of the Twelve Monkeys...where the virus was prior to mutation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was supposed to be 1995. RASPY VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Science isn't an exact science with these clowns.  You're lucky you didn't end up in ancient Egypt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLE is strapped on a gurney.  SCIENTISTS hover near-by, whispering.  The walls of the gloomy chamber are damp, sw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No mistakes this time, Cole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay alert.  Keep your eyes open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good thinking about that spider, Cole. Try and do something like that again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just relax now -- don't fight it.  We have to know exactly what's there so we can fix it. The gurney is being wheeled into a crudely welded steel t reminiscent of the cat scanner in County Hospital. COLE'S POV:  a last glimpse of anxious FACES, then the ch door is CLANGED shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DRIZZLING RAIN.  And SCREAMS.  COLE'S in a deep trench, n eyes wide with terror. What's going on? Where is he?  SOL in gas masks push urgently past him rushing toward their COMRADES who've been ripped apart by the shell that just fifteen yards away.  Muffled VOICES shout through gas mas in FRENCH.  COLE doesn't know it, but this is World War I Suddenly, a SERGEANT confronts him, shouting in French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (FRENCH, subtitled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your mask?!  And your clothes... and your weapon, you idiot?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  What?? COLE looks around desperately.  A horribly WOUNDED MAN is stretchered past them in the narrow trench.  Machine guns close at hand.  AAK AAK AAK.  A grenade EXPLODES.  Reacti foreign word, the SERGEANT jams his bayonet into COLE'S r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (FRENCH, subtitled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain!  A Kraut!  We got a Kraut!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.  Where am I? The CAPTAIN hurries over, snapping at COLE in German.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (GERMAN, subtitled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you get here, soldier?  What's your rank?  Where are your clothes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowning, GERMAN, subtitled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: German!  Speak German!  What are you doing here? VOICE (o.s.) (pleading in English)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta find 'em.  I gotta find 'em. Please, you gotta help me! COLE turns, sees... It's his friend, JOSE, the Puerto Rican kid from the next the "underground" time.  He's being carried past COLE now stretcher, blood all over his torso, horribly wounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole!  Oh, God, Cole, where are we? JOSE reaches out to COLE just as a PHOTOGRAPHER takes a F PICTURE of the kid being carried off on the stretcher.  S SHOTS RING OUT.  COLE goes down.  Hit in the leg! SOLDIERS in gas masks rush past him like giant insects. Looking to his left, COLE sees the CAPTAIN lying beside h from a chest wound, his gas mask half off. COLE is reaching for the mask when... A SHELL HITS CLOSE BY WITH AN ENORMOUS EXPLOSION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stunningly quiet.  We are on a placid campus looking at t dignified architecture of Breitrose Hall.  MOVING IN we F a large poster advertising "The Alexander Lectures, Sprin WE SKIM the listings (Jon Else on The Nuclear Agony, Dr. Miksztal on Biological Ethics, etc.) until we SETTLE ON..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADNESS AND APOCALYPTIC VISIONS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large screen dominates the auditorium stage.  On the sc a slide of an engraving from the Middle Ages showing a MA apparent agony, his mouth shaped to a scream, as he is re by PEASANTS.  The projector ZOOMS slowly in on the agoniz of this MADMAN as we HEAR RAILLY'S VOICE lecturing. RAILLY'S VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: According to the accounts of local officials at that time, this gentleman, judged to be about forty years of age, appeared suddenly in the village of Wyle near Stonehenge in the West of England in April of 1162.  Using unfamiliar words and speaking in a strange accent, the man made dire prognostications about a pestilence which he predicted would wipe out humanity in approximately 8OO years.  Deranged and hysterical, the man raped a young woman of the village, was taken into custody, but then mysteriously escaped and was not heard of again. WE DISCOVER RAILLY, six years older now, standing at a le in a pool of light.  She's dwarfed by the giant screen wh engraving is replaced by a series of slides of woodcuts s scenes of pestilence in the Middle Ages as she lectures t audience of mostly SCHOLARLY TYPES. RAILLY (cont.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In 1841, Mackay wrote, "During seasons of great pestilence, men have often believed the prophecies of crazed fanatics, that the end of the world was come."  Obviously, this plague/doomsday scenario is considerably more compelling when reality supports it in some form, whether it's the Bubonic Plague, smallpox, or AIDS.  In addition to these "natural" contagions, there are now technological horrors as well:  besides radiation, consider our lurking fear of germ warfare and its close approximation, chemical warfare, which first reared its ugly head in the deadly mustard gas attacks during the First World War. ON THE SCREEN, a SERIES of SLIDES show images of WORLD WA SOLDIERS in gas masks, in death throes, etc.. RAILLY'S VOICE (cont. o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During such an attack in the French trenches in October, 1917, we have an account of this soldier... ON THE SCREEN, a slide of an old deteriorated photograph JOSE, the Puerto Rican kid, strapped to a stretcher, bein by SOLDIERS through the trenches during an attack.  JOSE to be ranting madly as the projector ZOOMS CLOSER on his the image approximates Munch's famous painting. RAILLY'S VOICE (cant. o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- who, during an assault, was wounded by shrapnel and hospitalized behind the lines where Doctors discovered he had lost all comprehension of French but spoke English fluently, albeit in a regional dialect they didn't recognize. The man, although physically unaffected by the gas, was hysterical.  He claimed he had come from the future, that he was looking for a pure germ that would ultimately wipe mankind off the face of the earth in the year... 1995! The AUDIENCE gives a nervous CHUCKLE. ON THE SCREEN, a different old photograph of JOSE.  This he's in a military hospital, gaunt, haunted, very ill. RAILLY'S VOICE (cont. o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although seriously injured, the young soldier disappeared from the hospital before more data could be gathered.  No doubt, he was trying to carry on his mission to warn others, substituting for the agony of war...a self-inflicted agony we call the "Cassandra Complex". As RAILLY continues, we SCAN the AUDIENCE and DISCOVER MA RAILLY'S friend, and MARILOU'S HUSBAND, WAYNE CHANG, both attentively.  Further away, another MAN listens intently. shoulder-length carrot-colored hair.  His name is DR. PET RAILLY (cont.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cassandra, in Greek legend you will recall, was condemned to know the future but to be disbelieved when she foretold it.  Hence, the agony of foreknowledge combined with impotence to do anything about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stack of new books.  THE DOOMSDAY SYNDROME, Apocalyptic Visions of the Mentally Ill by Dr. Kathryn Railly Surrounded by enthusiastic members of the audience, RAILL seated at the table signing books but DR. PETERS has her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think, Dr. Railly, you have given your alarmists a bad name.  Surely there is very real and very convincing data that the planet cannot survive the excesses of the human race:  proliferation of atomic devices, uncontrolled breeding habits, the rape of the environment, the pollution of land, sea, and air.  In this context, isn't it obvious that "Chicken Little" represents the sane vision and that Homo Sapiens' motto, "Let's go shopping!" is the cry of the true lunatic? DR. PETERS smiles self-importantly at RAILLY as an elderl disheveled PROFESSOR elbows in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Railly -- please!  I wonder if you're aware of my own studies which indicate that certain cycles of the moon actually impact on the incidence of apocalyptic predictions as observed in urban emergency rooms and... As the PROFESSOR babbles, MARILOU MARTIN and her husband, CHANG, appear and whisper...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're leaving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reservation's at nine thirty -- it's getting late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Railly -- please -- this is very important!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking the professor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you're gonna be all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles, checks her watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be there in twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Railly, I simply cannot understand your exclusion of the moon in relation to apocalyptic dementia...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A full moon. COLLEAGUES in a VOLVO pull out of the parking lot, callin "Congratulations" to RAILLY. She waves back as she hurries to her black ACURA, one of cars left in the lot. The outside lights of Breitrose Hall go off. RAILLY seems to be alone in the lot as she fishes keys fr purse, unlocks her car door, starts to open it when... Suddenly, she's grabbed from behind in a choke-hold by a shadowy MAN looming out of the darkness behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in! Unable to scream, she writhes and kicks as he forces her front seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a gun. RAILLY freezes, terrified, as he opens the rear door and scrambles in behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fighting to suppress the quaver in her voice, RAILLY says

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can have my purse.  I have a lot of cash and credit... MAN'S VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start the car. Glancing in the rear view mirror, RAILLY sees penetrating peering out of the shadows, no other features. Half-turning in the seat, she holds out the keys to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here!  You can have the keys.  You can... He grabs her hair and yanks her head back hard, speaking into her ear, his face last in shadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The engine STARTS, the Acura backs up, then heads for the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steering fearfully, RAILLY hears him speak more calmly no MAN'S VOICE (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hurt you.  But I will. I've hurt people before when...when I had no choice.  Turn left. As she makes the turn, RAILLY glances in the rear view mi sees him unfolding a tattered map.  His face is lost in d but she glimpses ragged, torn clothing as he tries to rea map by the intermittent glow of passing street lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where... where are we going'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you to drive me to Philadelphia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled, horrified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's... that's more than 200 miles!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I can't walk there.  Turn here... I think... RAILLY obeys.  She glances in the mirror again, hesitates boldly switches on the dome light, holding her breath fea for his reaction. He grunts appreciatively.  Relieved, she looks in the mir again, trying to get a better look at him, but now his fe are concealed by the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you make me go with you, it's kidnapping.  That's a serious crime. If you let me go, you could just take the car and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how to drive!  We went underground when I was nine, I told you that.  When you come to the corner, turn right. Startled, RAILLY whirls, looks right at him. He's lowered the map.  It's COLE!  Haggard, unshaven, dir

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cole!  James Cole!  You escaped from a locked room six years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1989.  Six years for you.  There's the sign!  Right here! COLE is indicating a freeway entrance. RAILLY turns the wheel sharply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Acura veers up the ramp and onto the freeway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAILLY glances in the mirror, sees COLE settling back wea against the seat.  She says carefully...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe this is a coincidence, Mr. Cole.  Have you been...following me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told me you'd help me.  I know this isn't what you meant, but...I was desperate... no money...bum leg... sleeping on the streets. I probably smell bad.  Sorry about that. But then I saw your book in a store window with a notice about your lecture. (sudden pride)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can read, remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I remember. (a beat, then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you want to go to Philadelphia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the next step.  I checked out the Baltimore information, it was nothing. It's Philadelphia, that's where they are, the ones who killed everyone. (pointing suddenly, eagerly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zs that a radio?  Does it play music? RAILLY turns on the radio and immediately WE HEAR the SOU and the CRIES of gulls, background to an oozing baritone COMMERCIAL/RADIO (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a personal message to you. COLE sits up, alert, listening intently. COMMERCIAL/RADIO (cont. o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you at the end of your rope?  Are you dying to get away? COLE'S eyes narrow, concentrating on this personal messag COMMERCAIL/RADIO (cont. o.s.}

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Florida Keys are waiting for you. COLE frowns as the SOUND of breaking SURF and crying GULL the car.  It's confusing!  He blurts out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never seen the ocean! Observing his confusion in the mirror, RAILLY assumes her professional tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an advertisement, Mr. Cole.  You do understand that, don't you?  It's not really a special message to you. COLE frowns.  He did think it was for him, but she's prob

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You used to call me "James".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd prefer that? ... James...you don't really have a gun, do you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cynical laugh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody's got a gun.  In this city... He breaks off reacting to the RADIO MUSIC!  FATS DOMINO s "BLUEBERRY HILL"!  COLE grins, mouth agape, eyes wide lik

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you...can you make it louder?  I love hearing twentieth century music! Hearing music and breathing air! As RAILLY cranks up the volume, she watches the mirror incredulously, sees him stick his head out the window int wind, mouth open, "eating" the air hungrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "BLUEBERRY HILL" BLARES as the Acura, COLE'S head out the window, zips past a sign at 65 mph. The sign says, "PHILADELPHIA 233 MILES."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAILLY glances in the mirror at the nut in the rear seat head out the window.  what can she do?  Just then, while trying to figure something out, an ANNOUNCER'S VOICE brea ANNOUNCER/RADIO (o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This just in from Fresno, California: emergency crews are converging on a cornfield where playmates of nine year old Ricky Neuman say they saw him disappear right before their eyes. COLE pulls his head back inside with a frown, troubled no ANNOUNCER/RADIO (cont. o.s.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Neuman apparently stepped into an abandoned well shaft and is lodged somewhere in the narrow 150 foot pipe, possibly alive, possibly seriously injured.  Playmates claim they heard him cry out faintly but since then there has been no contact with...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Never cry wolf!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father told me that.  "Never cry wolf."  Then people won't believe you if...something really happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "If something really happens"...like what, James?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something bad.  Is that all the music? I don't want to hear this stuff... RAILLY glances at him as she scans stations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did something terrible happen to you when you were a child?  Something so bad...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhhh, that one!  Can we hear that one? It's IVORY JOE HUNTER singing, "SINCE I MET YOU, BABY". IVORY JOE/RADIO (o.s.)
